author: By John Branch
title: Britain won the mixed medley relay, a new event.
description: China took silver and Australia won bronze. Italy came in fourth and the U.S., anchored by Caelab Dressel, finished fifth.
content: TOKYO — Britain won the mixed medley relay in a time of 3 minutes 37.58, setting a world record in the first time the event was held at the Olympics. China took silver and Australia bronze, followed by Italy and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: An Unlikely Pair, Portman and Sinema Steer Infrastructure Deal
description: An Ohio Republican who is retiring after decades in Washington has teamed with an Arizona Democrat in her first term to try to secure an agreement on one of President Biden’s top priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — It had scarcely been 24 hours since a breakthrough vote in the Senate to move forward with a $1 trillion infrastructure bill when the two lead negotiators on the deal, Senators Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, and Kyrsten Sinema, Democrat of Arizona, knew they had a problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tommy Trenchard
title: In South Africa, Poachers Now Traffic in Tiny Succulent Plants
description: Police search the desert trying to track down the poachers selling Conophytums to collectors worldwide, threatening to wipe out rare plants in the wild.
content: STEINKOPF, South Africa — On a moonless night in the desert in the far west of South Africa, Avrill Kaffer had just finished making a sale when vehicles with flashing lights emerged out of the darkness and an officer from the Stock Theft and Endangered Species Unit leapt from behind a nearby bush, ordering him to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Elsie Chen
title: Police in China Detain Canadian Pop Star on Suspicion of Rape
description: Kris Wu, a 30-year-old celebrity, is the most prominent figure in China to be held over #MeToo allegations.
content: The police in Beijing said Saturday they had detained Kris Wu, a popular Canadian Chinese singer, on suspicion of rape amid a #MeToo controversy that has set off outrage in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: New Zealand women’s rugby sevens grabs gold.
description: The Kiwis ran away from the French in the second half.
content: New Zealand’s women’s rugby sevens team captured the gold medal on Saturday, beating France, 26-12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: You Anon
description: Reconsidering pseudonymity and what it means to “be yourself” online.
content: In early July, when England’s soccer team lost the European Championship final to Italy on its home turf, the crushing defeat was followed by a torrent of racist abuse on social media directed at the team’s Black players. The messages — part of an ongoing pattern of social media bigotry — were condemned by politicians, platforms, teammates and fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: A Brief History of Summer Reading
description: We rarely talk about spring books or winter reading. What is it about summer that inspired a whole genre of its own?
content: When the days get longer and the mercury begins to rise, the books appear. Sunscreen-dappled paperbacks are tucked into beach bags and backpacks, sprinkled across picnic tables and dropped into the crooks of hammocks. Like their siblings the summer blockbuster and the song of the summer, they come: The season of summer reading has arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Jacey Fortin
title: Stranded Killer Whale Survives With Help of Good Samaritans
description: Rescuers and wildlife officials kept it cool and wet while waiting for a rising tide. The orca returned to sea about six hours after it was spotted on the rugged shores of an Alaskan island.
content: Boaters in Alaska came upon a peculiar sight on Thursday: A 20-foot-long killer whale was on the shore, stuck in a crevice of rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Good Fences Make Good Neighbors? Not at Opus 40.
description: The scenic vistas of this landscape art and the legacy of its creator, Harvey Fite, are being challenged by a persistent feud and a big fence.
content: SAUGERTIES, N.Y. — The 6.5-acre bluestone labyrinth rising out of a quarry here is one of the marvels of the Hudson Valley, an artistic tour de force by a self-taught sculptor who spent more than half his life creating it with thousands of rocks, infinite patience and no cement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oskar Garcia
title: Pablo Carreño Busta beat Novak Djokovic to win the bronze in men’s singles tennis.
description: Djokovic came into the Olympics chasing a Golden Slam. He leaves the Tokyo Games without any medal after withdrawing from the mixed doubles tournament.
content: TOKYO — Pablo Carreño Busta, a highly ranked Spaniard who has twice reached the semifinals of the U.S. Open but never broken through in a big way on the professional tour, outlasted Novak Djokovic, the top men’s player in the world, to win a bronze medal at the Tokyo Games on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaëlle Fournier
title: The Long Kiss Goodbye: Will Covid End the French Bise Forever?
description: Social distancing made the cheek kiss a much rarer greeting, and polling suggests it may stay that way. Some say good riddance, but others miss the warmth of times past.
content: Twice a year, Louise Al-Hakkak would sit on her front porch in Burgundy, waiting for her sister Flora and dreading the moment of “la bise.” In this Franco-Iraqi family, only Flora enjoyed France’s traditional two-kiss greeting on the cheeks. For Ms. Al-Hakkak and her father, “It was more a chore than anything else.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: For Tenants Nationwide, a Scramble to Pay Months of Rent or Face Eviction
description: A federal eviction moratorium is scheduled to end on Saturday. Many tenants are packing up and facing an uncertain future.
content: For almost a year, a federal moratorium on evictions allowed tenants who suffered economic losses from the coronavirus pandemic to stay in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karla Cornejo Villavicencio
title: The Spectacle of Latinx Colorism
description: The idea of sameness can devastate as much as it can connect.
content: This summer’s controversy over the underrepresentation of dark-skinned Afro-Latinos in “In the Heights,” the Hollywood adaptation of the Broadway musical, laid bare the cancer of colorism in Latinx communities in the United States. The reckoning was long overdue, a pain that goes back as long as our community has existed. And the mainstream media was enraptured. It created what I think of as the spectacle — el espectáculo. I haven’t seen as high a demand for Latinx voices since the Pulse shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Ta-Ta to ‘Teetering Tabloids’: Keith Kelly Signs Off
description: For 23 years, his Media Ink column for The New York Post was a must-read for magazine machers. What’s next?
content: The happiest man in Midtown Manhattan last Monday morning might have been Keith J. Kelly, the longtime media columnist for The New York Post. It was the first day of his retirement and he was puffing on a Cohiba while perambulating down West 55th street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Swimming and golf wrap up as track and field heats up on Day 9.
description: All the day’s results as they happen from Tokyo.
content: TOKYO — The middle weekend of any Olympics is always a big one. Swimming wraps up, track gets going, and the team events approach their knockout stages. And it seems like the deluge of events at the Tokyo Games hits a peak on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Beth Treffeisen
title: ‘It’s Nowhere Near Over’: A Beach Town’s Gust of Freedom, Then a U-turn
description: Provincetown, Mass., the quirky community at the tip of Cape Cod, thought it was safe to return to prepandemic partying. It wasn’t.
content: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — By the Fourth of July, Provincetown’s tourist season had built to a prepandemic thrum. Restaurants were booked solid, and snaking lines formed outside the dance clubs. There were conga lines, drag brunches and a pervasive, joyous sense of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: More than 200 staff members at 2 San Francisco hospitals have tested positive, most in breakthrough Delta infections.
description: Vaccinations warded off severe Covid for most of the workers, who tested positive this month; two required hospitalization.
content: At least 233 staff members at two major San Francisco hospitals, most of them fully vaccinated, tested positive for the coronavirus this month, and most, according to a hospital official, involved the highly contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Simone Manuel failed to qualify for the women’s 50 free final.
description: The miss for Manuel came after she also failed to qualify for the Olympics in the 100 freestyle, her signature event.
content: Simone Manuel of the United States failed to qualify for the 50-meter freestyle final after finishing 11th out of 16 swimmers in semifinal heats in a time of 24.63 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Grief and Fury After Surviving Night of Terror
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 31, 2021.
content: “In my mind, everybody was dead, because if the president could die, everybody else could have died too.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Fandos
title: Already Distorting Jan. 6, G.O.P. Now Concocts Entire Counternarrative
description: In the Republicans’ disinformation campaign, the arrested Capitol rioters are political prisoners and Speaker Nancy Pelosi is to blame for the attack.
content: In the hours and days after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, rattled Republican lawmakers knew exactly who was to blame: Donald J. Trump. Loyal allies began turning on him. Top Republicans vowed to make a full break from his divisive tactics and dishonesties. Some even discussed removing him from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Demand for shots is increasing in less vaccinated states under siege from the Delta variant.
description: Data from the C.D.C. shows that many people in states like Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri are now receiving their first doses. On Friday, more than 850,000 total shots were recorded in the U.S.
content: Vaccinations are rising in U.S. states where lagging demand left entire regions vulnerable to a Delta-driven surge of coronavirus cases. The shift offers a sign of hope, even as the country’s known cases since the start of the pandemic surpassed 35 million on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon take us deep underground for a secretive little acrostic.
content: ACROSTIC — Full confession (and probably no surprise): This is my favorite flavor of acrostic, a little factoid-filled puzzle about the natural world. I think one a week would be delightful. Today’s passage is from a book called “Great Adaptations” by Kenneth Catania, about a variety of niche creatures who have evolved perfectly to their environments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman, Jan Hoffman, Margot Sanger-Katz and Tim Arango
title: Who Are the Unvaccinated in America? There’s No One Answer.
description: One segment of people who have avoided shots is vehemently opposed to the idea. But there is a second group, surveys suggest, that is still deciding.
content: As coronavirus cases rise across the United States, the fight against the pandemic is focused on an estimated 93 million people who are eligible for shots but have chosen not to get them. These are the Americans who are most vulnerable to serious illness from the highly contagious Delta variant and most likely to carry the virus, spreading it further.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden, Republicans and the Pandemic Blame Game
description: G.O.P. resistance to public health measures has helped fuel Covid’s resurgence. But the president will be left to clean up the mess.
content: President Biden is in a tough spot: He campaigned on the ideas that he had the team to manage a pandemic and that his five-decade career as a Washington deal maker was just the ticket to overcome the country’s political polarization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Have a Question for Eric Adams?
description: The Democratic nominee for mayor of New York City will have a lot of work to do if he’s elected. What do you want to know?
content: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, is almost certain to become the next mayor of New York City. He won the Democratic primary in a city where registered Democrats vastly outnumber Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: India’s married archers: ‘We are a powerful couple.’
description: Known as Dee-Das in India, Deepika Kumari and Atanu Das are one of two pairs of married archers at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: TOKYO — When love’s arrow struck, Deepika Kumari and Atanu Das were ready with their own quivers. Known as Dee-Das in India, the couple are one of two pairs of married archers at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Are Your Neighbor’s Pesticides Bad for Your Children, Pets and Plants?
description: Under New York law, neighbors must divulge which chemicals they’re using to kill pests. But of course, there are loopholes and exceptions.
content: Q: I live in Westchester County, N.Y., and received a notice from my neighbors that they will be applying commercial pesticides to their lawn. I have small children, a dog and a large vegetable garden, and I’m concerned about the pesticides drifting onto my property and harming all of them. How concerned should I be, and what can I do to protect my family?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Why Do Republicans Hate Cops?
description: Turning their backs on the ones who had their backs.
content: WASHINGTON — It was, I must admit, a virtuoso performance by Sean Hannity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Accessible
description: Brian Thomas and Brooke Husic are back with stumpers of all sizes.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Wow! The top half of this grid is a tough nut to crack, which makes the “belt” at 32-Across exceptionally wry. Brian Thomas and Brooke Husic collaborated on another hard Saturday puzzle back in June; these are great puzzles for aficionados, because they pose challenge after challenge, but even if you feel trepidation about Saturdays you will find that a little risk-taking will push you over the top, a very satisfying feeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oskar Garcia
title: Belinda Bencic of Switzerland wins tennis singles gold.
description: Bencic could win two golds in Tokyo if she wins a doubles tournament on Sunday.
content: TOKYO — Belinda Bencic of Switzerland won gold in the women’s singles tennis tournament on Saturday night, beating Marketa Vondrousova of the Czech Republic and positioning herself to be one of very few players to win singles and doubles gold in the same Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday evening includes golf, swimming and baseball.
description: Caeleb Dressel takes aim at another gold, and baseball teams from Mexico and Israel face off.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday evening and overnight. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Home Prices Are Soaring. Is That the Fed’s Problem?
description: Low interest rates are one reason that the housing market has taken off. They are far from the only one.
content: Robert S. Kaplan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, has been nervously eyeing the housing market as he ponders the path ahead for monetary policy. Home prices are rising at a double-digit pace this year. The typical house in and around the city he calls home sold for $306,031 in June of this year, Zillow estimates, up from $261,710 a year earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Mourning Families Seek Solace From the ‘Grief Purgatory’ of Covid-19
description: The pandemic has left hundreds of thousands of Americans alone in bereavement, unable to plan proper funerals for their loved ones. Now, they’re planning larger celebrations of life.
content: The obituary had promised memorial services at a later date, so in May, Jessica Zimmerman-Selvidge sifted through photos of her father, trying to find the best ones for a celebration of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Demonstrations against France’s vaccine pass surge for a third weekend, even as cases rise.
description: The government’s health pass law was passed by Parliament and is expected to get a final greenlight from a top constitutional council next week.
content: PARIS — Pascale Collino, 64, is far more afraid of the Covid-19 vaccines than of the disease itself. So when the French government decided to implement a new health pass policy barring those without proof of vaccination or a recent negative test from many indoor venues, she took to the streets in protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: We Asked Daves About Dave, Marcus and Other First-Name Money Apps
description: When’s the last time you went into a bank branch? Maybe it’s time to consider those friendly sounding financial start-ups.
content: Dave and his bros are having a moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Strong Is Trump’s Grip on the G.O.P.?
description: Weaker than he wants, but strong enough to win the nomination once again.
content: This was a week of setbacks for Donald Trump in his attempt to maintain a firm hold on the Republican Party till 2024 and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Matthew Futterman
title: The Rise of Mixed-Gender Relays at the Tokyo Olympics
description: In Tokyo, men and women are teaming up in a series of mixed-gender events that are making their Olympic debuts.
content: TOKYO — After winning bronze in one of the new Olympic events at the Tokyo Games, Alejandra Valencia of Mexico recalled the moment when her partner nearly blew it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Ken Belson
title: Olympics’ First Openly Transgender Woman Stokes Debate on Fairness
description: Laurel Hubbard, a 43-year-old weight lifter from New Zealand, will compete on Monday, as some question her right to be at the Games.
content: TOKYO — When Laurel Hubbard, a 43-year-old weight lifter from New Zealand, makes her first attempt in the women’s heavyweight competition on Monday, she will become the first openly transgender female athlete to compete at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Vaccine Holdouts Face Training Camp Scrutiny
description: Though 88.5 percent of all N.F.L. players had received at least one vaccine dose through Friday, some players voiced their hesitance to be inoculated.
content: When asked by reporters Tuesday if he had received the Covid-19 vaccine, Indianapolis Colts defensive lineman DeForest Buckner nodded his head and smiled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Oster
title: A Smarter Way to Make Decisions About Your Kids
description: What parents can learn from the strategies of well-run companies.
content: When we become parents, we expect to be many things: someone who wakes in the middle of the night and who cleans up food from the floor; someone who comforts, who loves, who disciplines, who celebrates. What we perhaps did not expect is to take on the job of logistics manager. It creeps up on us as children age. The floor may get cleaner and the midnight wake-ups less frequent, but in their place is the stress of competing demands on our children’s time and ours. Which school to go to and how to get there? Is evening math tutoring necessary? What do we do about summer camp? How can three children with two parents be at three birthday parties on Saturday at 2 p.m.?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Trump Has Built War Chest of More Than $100 Million
description: In the first half of 2021, the former president raised far more money online than any other Republican, federal records show. But his team claimed he had raised more than he actually did.
content: Despite departing from office and being barred from the leading social media platforms, former President Donald J. Trump was the Republican Party’s most dominant fund-raiser in the first half of 2021 and ended June with a war chest of more than $100 million, according to new federal campaign filings made this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: ‘It Feels Like We’re Just Waiting to Die’: Hong Kong Targets Student Unions
description: The authorities are clamping down on universities, which they consider hotbeds for unrest. The groups say they are fighting for survival.
content: HONG KONG — The police arrived at the University of Hong Kong around 3 p.m., wearing black vests marking them as national security officers. They cordoned off the offices of the student union, combed its interior and seized several bins of material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Katie Ledecky won the women’s 800-meter freestyle.
description: She defeated a budding rival, Ariarne Titmus of Australia.
content: TOKYO — Katie Ledecky concluded her Tokyo Olympics with another gold medal in an event she has dominated her entire career, the 800-meter freestyle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Russia’s New Form of Organized Crime Is Menacing the World
description: Old crime, new technology. There's an answer to the plague of ransomware.
content: The screen goes blank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris
title: ‘All Things Seemed Possible for Humanity’: Why We Watch the Olympics
description: New York Times readers recall the moments from Olympics history that moved them.
content: My 4-year-old buried his head in my hip and let out a short, gaspy shriek. It could have been thrill. It could have been fear. Maybe both? We were watching a video of Simone Biles’s qualifying floor routine at the Tokyo Olympics — the first Games my son will experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Friday night includes several swimming events.
description: BMX and trampoline are also on the air.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Friday evening and overnight. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
title: Key Afghan City in Danger of Falling to the Taliban
description: Government reinforcements arrived Saturday in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, but people were fleeing their homes and a hospital in the city had been bombed.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — An important city in Afghanistan’s south was in danger of falling to the Taliban on Saturday as their fighters pushed toward its center despite concerted American and Afghan airstrikes in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin J. Delaney
title: ‘This Could Have Been a Zoom Meeting’: Companies Rethink Travel
description: Before business travel fully takes off again, some companies are taking steps to rein it in.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Body of Reuters Photographer Was Mutilated in Taliban Custody, Officials Say
description: The body of Danish Siddiqui, a Pulitzer Prize winner killed in Afghanistan, was unrecognizable when it was brought to a Kandahar hospital, one official said.
content: NEW DELHI — The body of Danish Siddiqui, a Pulitzer Prize-winning Reuters photojournalist who was killed in Afghanistan this month, was badly mutilated while in the custody of the Taliban, officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Haidt and Jean M. Twenge
title: This Is Our Chance to Pull Teenagers Out of the Smartphone Trap
description: Loneliness among students has soared worldwide. It doesn't have to be like that.
content: As students return to school in the coming weeks, there will be close attention to their mental health. Many problems will be attributed to the Covid pandemic, but in fact we need to look back further, to 2012.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Biden Promised to Restore the Iran Nuclear Deal. Now It Risks Derailment.
description: Both sides have much to lose if a delicate negotiation over limiting Iran’s activities in return for a lifting of sanctions falls short.
content: WASHINGTON — Days before a new hard-line president is set to be inaugurated in Iran, Biden administration officials have turned sharply pessimistic about their chances of quickly restoring the nuclear deal that President Donald J. Trump dismantled, fearing that the new government in Tehran is speeding ahead on nuclear research and production and preparing new demands for the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Here’s a preview of swimming races today.
description: Katie Ledecky and Caeleb Dressel are among the swimmers who are chasing gold on Saturday.
content: TOKYO — Swimming today (Saturday morning in Tokyo, Friday night in the U.S.) presents the second-to-last day of the competition, the last race for Katie Ledecky and another chance for Caeleb Dressel to win gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: ‘The war has changed.’ In just days, the U.S. shifts tactics against the virus.
description: Delta-driven surges are prompting new measures from the federal government, states and cities, companies and the military, as well as defiant rejections.
content: What a difference a week makes. In just a few days, the state and local authorities have imposed mask mandates, companies have put off returning workers to their offices, and the federal government and the military have pressured their employees to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Kaylee McKeown of Australia won the 200-meter women’s backstroke.
description: She defeated Kylie Masse of Canada and Emily Seebohm of Australia.
content: Kaylee McKeown of Australia won the 200-meter women’s backstroke in a time of 2 minutes 4.68 seconds, defeating Kylie Masse of Canada and Emily Seebohm of Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Romain Molina
title: Accusations of Sexual Abuse Continue to Roil Basketball in Mali
description: One Malian basketball leader has been suspended and another jailed in a scandal that has cast a shadow on the president of the sport’s worldwide governing body.
content: The president of Mali’s basketball federation has been suspended and the West African nation’s former women’s youth national coach has been jailed on charges of sexually abusing players, according to the country’s sports ministry and the prosecutor in the assault case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: San Marino becomes the smallest country to win an Olympic medal.
description: San Marino waited 61 years for its first Olympic medal. With a population of roughly 30,000, it is the smallest country to win an Olympic medal, surpassing Bermuda
content: TOKYO — San Marino waited 61 years for its first Olympic medal, which came on Thursday. Then it waited two days for its next one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Yoder
title: Cults, College Dropouts and the Art of Control in Two New Story Collections
description: Alix Ohlin’s “We Want What We Want” and Genevieve Plunkett’s “Prepare Her” explore desire and alienation.
content: WE WANT WHAT WE WANT Stories By Alix Ohlin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Wong
title: After 670 Days, the Blue Jays Finally Returned to Canada
description: With a pandemic-forced sojourn to Buffalo and Florida now complete, Toronto’s exciting young team got a chance to experience its actual home crowd.
content: TORONTO — When the coronavirus sent the world into lockdown in the spring of 2020, the area surrounding Rogers Centre in the heart of downtown Toronto became something of a desolate wasteland. The familiar sounds of the walk-up crowd on game day and scalpers shouting at the top of their lungs were replaced by socially distanced outdoor yoga groups, residents taking their daily walks with their pets, and the occasional tennis enthusiast working on their forehead against the brick wall adjacent to the stadium entrance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: A Plant That ‘Cannot Die’ Reveals Its Genetic Secrets
description: Events in the genome of Welwitschia have given it the ability to survive in an unforgiving desert for thousands of years.
content: The longest-lived leaves in the plant kingdom can be found only in the harsh, hyperarid desert that crosses the boundary between southern Angola and northern Namibia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: The U.S. broadcast on Saturday morning includes finals in women’s tennis and archery.
description: Judo concludes with the sport’s first mixed-gender competition, and the U.S. baseball team plays South Korea.
content: Here are some highlights of U.S. broadcast coverage on Saturday morning. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Frenchy Cannoli, Ardent Evangelist for Hashish, Dies at 64
description: He left France at 18 for a nearly two-decade sojourn to India, Nepal, Mexico and Morocco to learn the secrets of making hash and became an authority.
content: Frenchy Cannoli, a renowned hashish evangelist who spent 18 years as a nomad learning to make the drug from the resin of the cannabis plant in rural parts of Asia, Africa and Mexico, died on July 18 in San Francisco. He was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Maitreyi Ramakrishnan of ‘Never Have I Ever’ Loves Van Gogh
description: The 19-year-old actress visits New York City and goes to an “art rave.”
content: Cobalt and ultramarine blue swirled on the floors and walls. A moon appeared. Then stars. And the tangled branches of cypress trees. “‘Starry Night,’” Maitreyi Ramakrishnan murmured on a sultry July morning. “This is like the headliner act.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Alexandra E. Petri
title: A Nigerian sprinter is suspended after a failed drug test.
description: Ten other athletes from Nigeria were told they did not meet out-of-competition testing requirements leading up to the Olympics.
content: Track and field’s drug testing agency temporarily suspended a Nigerian sprinter after a failed drug test, the first drug-related suspension of an active athlete at the Tokyo Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica wins the 100-meter dash.
description: Thompson-Herah, the defending gold medalist in the event, finished in 10.61 seconds.
content: TOKYO — Elaine Thompson-Herah of Jamaica on Saturday repeated as the Olympic champion in the women’s 100 meters, outsprinting a field that included Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a two-time former champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Fatima Faizi
title: As Fears Grip Afghanistan, Hundreds of Thousands Flee
description: With the Taliban sweeping across much of the country, at least 30,000 Afghans are leaving each week. Many more have been displaced within Afghanistan’s borders.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Haji Sakhi decided to flee Afghanistan the night he saw two Taliban members drag a young woman from her home and lash her on the sidewalk. Terrified for his three daughters, he crammed his family into a car the next morning and barreled down winding dirt roads into Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Off Brand
description: Matthew Stock’s puzzle takes us off the beaten path.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is an eccentric grid by a newish constructor, Matthew Stock, who works for a math-education nonprofit in East St. Louis, Ill. It’s his sixth puzzle for The Times and his second Sunday crossword, all from 2021 (you may remember “Karaoke Bars,” which spun through some pop favorites). I think today’s puzzle is a lot of fun and I found it to be one of the more difficult big grids that we’ve had recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elissa Sanci
title: No Pool? Here’s How to Make a Splash in the Yard Anyway.
description: With the right tools and a little imagination, anyone can turn an outdoor space into a makeshift water park.
content: With more than a month of summer left — one that’s shaping up to be among the hottest on record — a cool dip in the water is an ideal way to spend a blistering August afternoon. Even if you aren’t fortunate enough to have your own in-ground pool, you can still create a splash in your own backyard — you just have to get creative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Katie Ledecky and Caeleb Dressel delivered yet again.
description: Ledecky added to her medal haul — she has 10 total across three Olympics, including seven golds.
content: TOKYO — It was the Katie and Caeleb Show, an ongoing series at swimming, as the Americans continued their medal haul at the Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: U.S. fencers wear pink masks to protest against teammate accused of sexual misconduct.
description: Alen Hadzic, an alternate on the men’s fencing team, was left wearing a black mask while three of his teammates wore pink ones during competition on Friday.
content: Alen Hadzic, an alternate on the U.S. Olympic fencing team who is accused of sexual misconduct, has been ostracized in Tokyo and prevented from staying in the Olympic Village.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Matthew Goldstein and Conor Dougherty
title: Eviction Freeze Set to Lapse as Biden Housing Aid Effort Lags
description: The administration made a last-ditch, failed appeal to extend the moratorium to buy more time for states to distribute rental aid.
content: A nationwide moratorium on residential evictions is set to expire on Saturday after a last-minute effort by the Biden administration to win an extension failed, putting hundreds of thousands of tenants at risk of losing shelter, while tens of billions in federal funding intended to pay their back rent sit untapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Caeleb Dressel won the men’s 100-meter butterfly, setting a world record.
description: He set a world record with a time of 49.45.
content: Caeleb Dressel of the United States won his third gold medal of these Olympics, setting a world record in the 100-meter butterfly with a time of 49.45 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Female Sprinters Take the Spotlight at Tokyo’s ‘Superfast’ Track
description: The women’s 100-meter dash headlines Day 2 on the track. Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce of Jamaica, a top contender, called the attention on the event “long overdue.”
content: TOKYO — For years, the 100-meter dash was synonymous with one stupendously fast human: Usain Bolt, who won three straight Olympic titles before he retired in 2017. He has since occupied his time with dabbling in professional soccer, selling cars, traveling the world as a bon vivant and becoming a new father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: New Rule Raises Question: Who’ll Pay for All the Covid Tests?
description: With the Delta variant surging, many companies have decided that unvaccinated workers will need to get regular testing.
content: Spurred by rising Covid cases and the Delta variant’s spread, a wave of major employers announced the same rule for unvaccinated workers this week: They will need to submit to regular surveillance testing. The new requirement raises a thorny question: Who pays for those coronavirus tests?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tokyo Olympics on Saturday: Ups and Downs
description: Elaine Thompson-Herah extends her reign, Novak Djokovic loses and a different set of gymnasts bounce toward gold.
content: Elaine Thompson-Herah extends her reign, Novak Djokovic loses and a different set of gymnasts bounce toward gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Ward, Lazaro Gamio, Larry Buchanan, Jeremy White, Weiyi Cai, Bedel Saget, Tessa Barton, Alexandre Devaux, Or Fleisher, Niko Koppel, Mark McKeague and Peter Whidden
title: How Fast the Jamaican Sprinters Ran to Sweep the Women’s 100 Meters
description: The gold medalist, Elaine Thompson-Herah, averaged more than 21 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.61 seconds.
content: The gold medalist, Elaine Thompson-Herah, averaged more than 21 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.61 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Buchanan, Matthew Futterman, Taylor Johnston, Jasmine C. Lee, Eleanor Lutz and Joe Ward
title: For Katie Ledecky, the Longer the Race the Better
description: How Katie Ledecky’s competitors are closing the gap on her dominance in the pool.
content: How Katie Ledecky’s competitors are closing the gap on her dominance in the pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby
title: As Covid Cases Rise All Over U.S., Lower Vaccination Rates Point to Worse Outcomes
description: Counties with low vaccination rates continue to bear the brunt of the highly contagious Delta variant, and some are seeing their highest case rates of the entire pandemic.
content: Counties with low vaccination rates continue to bear the brunt of the highly contagious Delta variant, and some are seeing their highest case rates of the entire pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Delta Variant Drives Global Virus Surge, W.H.O. Warns
description: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general, said a worldwide rise in Covid-19 cases has disparately impacted poorer countries with lower vaccination rates, and that deaths in Africa have spiked 80 percent in four weeks.
content: Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the World Health Organization’s director general, said a worldwide rise in Covid-19 cases has disparately impacted poorer countries with lower vaccination rates, and that deaths in Africa have spiked 80 percent in four weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: July 31, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 31, 2021.
content: An article on March 30 about Liberty University’s decision to reopen its campus after its spring break referred imprecisely to the university medical staff’s concerns about Covid-19 on campus. While several students reported to the campus health center with respiratory illnesses, the staff did not conclude that their symptoms indicated that there was a Covid-19 outbreak on campus. One student tested positive.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Vulgar Anti-Biden Banner: Protected Free Speech?
description: Readers discuss an editorial defending a New Jersey woman’s right to display crude political banners.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
